fr:title.text: Container Combinatorics: Monads and Lax Monoidal Functors

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Container Combinatorics: Monads and Lax Monoidal Functors

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This can be extended to a fully faithful functor from the category of monad containers and monad container maps to the category of \mathbf {Set}-monads and monad maps. [uustalu2017]

This morning and yesterday evening I was trying to work out what monad containers correspond to algebraic theories. Since algebraic theories interpret finitary monads, I first worked out when monad containers are finitary; lemma 1.7.3 from Joachim Kock's "Notes on Polynomial Functors" shows that this is exactly when the position sets are finite.

By considering the algebras for a monad conatiner, it became pretty clear that the algebraic theory corresponding to a monad container essentially has an operation for each shape which interact in accordance with the monad container equalities.
  290lsd-0019lsd-0019.xmlMonad container algebrasDefinition2024129Chris Purdy
An algebra for a monad container (S 	riangleright  P, \iota , \sigma , 	ext {pr}) is a pair (A, \alpha ) of a set A and a map \alpha  : \prod _{s : S} (P\ s 	o  A) 	o  A, satisfying:
        egin {align*}       \alpha \ \iota \ (\lambda  \_ . a) &= a\       \alpha \ (\sigma \ s\ f)\ (g \circ  	ext {pr}) &= \alpha \ s\ (\lambda  p . \alpha \ (f\ p)\ (g\ p))      \end {align*}   
  292lsd-0020lsd-0020.xmlAlgebraic theories for cartesian monad containersProposition2024129Chris Purdy
The Set-functor interpretation of a finitary cartesian monad container (S 	riangleright  P, \iota , \sigma ) is the same as that of the algebraic theory consisting of an operation \lbrack

  I'm only considering cartesian monad containers for now, since their algebraic theories were much easier to describe - I'm not exactly sure how to phrase the equations in the non-cartesian case. For example, \lbrack 
egthinspace \lbrack  \iota  brack 
egthinspace brack  is not necessarily unary in that case, and \lbrack 
egthinspace \lbrack  \sigma \ s\ f brack 
egthinspace brack  may have fewer arguments than the sum of the arities of each \lbrack 
egthinspace \lbrack  f(i) brack 
egthinspace brack  - the resulting equations feel rather unnatural.oplus_
I think [gambinokock2013] describes all of this in a more general form. A good reference describing filtered colimits is the Stacks project.

An aside: I also found this presentation by Steve Awodey that describes the link between polynomial functors/monads and models of type theory, which probably links closely to the concept of \Sigma -universes.

EDIT (12/12/24): I realised that I was missing the associativity equation for the definition of the algebraic theory for a finitary cartesian monad container, and in the process realised that finitary cartesian monad containers are exactly non-symmetric operads!

To show this, consider (S \triangleright P, \iota , \sigma ). The set (or type) of operations for each n : \mathbb {N} is given by n \mapsto \sum _{s : S} |\negthinspace | P\ s \cong n |\negthinspace | where \iota is the identity operation, and \sigma is composition. All operations have finite arity by the finitary assumption on the monad container.

That monad containers were generalisations of non-symmetric operads (in this way) was already noticed by Tarmo Uustalu in [uustalu2017], but an explicit construction showing how they can be recovered was not given.

The Coproduct monad container for a set E is given by the data 1 + E \triangleright T where T\ (\text {inl}\ *) := 1, T\ (\text {inr}\ \_) := 0 and: \begin {align*} \iota &:= \text {inl}\ *\\ \sigma \ (\text {inl}\ *)\ f &:= f\ *\\ \sigma \ (\text {inr}\ e)\ f &:= \text {inr}\ e\\ \text {pr}\ * &:= (* , *) \end {align*} This is the unique monad container structure that you can give the container 1 + E \triangleright T [uustalu2017]. This also happens to be a cartesian monad container. \text {pr} is well-defined up to function extensionality by induction on its implicit arguments.

Let (S \triangleright P, \iota , \sigma , \text {pr}) be a monad container. We call the monad container commutative when the following laws hold: \begin {align*} \sigma \ a\ (\lambda \_ . b) &= \sigma \ b\ (\lambda \_ . a)\\ \text {pr}_1\ p &= \text {pr}_2\ p\\ \text {pr}_2\ p &= \text {pr}_1\ p \end {align*} The equations for \text {pr} holds given the first equation. Commutative monad containers interpret exactly the commutative monads (w.r.t. cartesian product) for container functors. [uustalu2017]
